items.detail: “Dialogic: A Toolkit for Generative Interactive Dialog.” Howe, Daniel C. Proceedings of Foundations of Digital Games (FDG) 2020, Association for Computing Machinery (ACM), New York, USA. Awards: Exceptional Paper, Best Paper Nominee

“A Critique of Surprise in Generative Art.” Soderman, Braxton and Daniel C Howe. In Algorithmic and Generative Art, edited by Aceti, Lanfranco, Kris Paulsen, and Meredith Hoy. Leonardo Electronic Almanac. Volume 22, Issue 4. March 15, 2019, Cambridge: MIT Press.

“Advertising Positions: Data Portraiture as Aesthetic Critique.” Howe, Daniel C. et al. In Leonardo, Volume 51, Issue 4, August 2018. p.413-418. Cambridge: MIT Press. Originally published in ACM Trans. Graphics.
“You Have Pressure, I Have Pressure: Hacking, Art & Activism in Hong Kong.” Howe, Daniel C. Chapter 3, in The Field Guide to Hacking. 2018. Hong Kong: Dim Sum Press.

“Surveillance Countermeasures: Expressive Privacy via Obfuscation.” Howe, Daniel C. In A Peer–reviewed Journal About (APRJA). Christian Ulrik Andersen and Geoff Cox (eds.) Vol. 4, Issue 1. Aarhus: Digital Aesthetics Research Center, Aarhus University, Berlin
“The Readers Project: Procedural Agents and Literary Vectors.” Howe, Daniel C. and Cayley, J. In Leonardo. Aug 2011, Vol. 44, No. 4, MIT Press, Cambridge, MA, p317–324.
“The Aesthetics of Generative Literature: Lessons from an Electronic Writing Workshop.” Howe, Daniel C. and Soderman, A. B. In Hyperrhiz: New Media Cultures, Visionary Landscapes, Vol. 6. Fall

“A Statement by The Readers Project concerning contemporary literary practice, digital mediation, intellectual property, and associated moral rights.” Cayley, J. and Howe, Daniel C., in Whose Book is it Anyway?: A View From Elsewhere on Publishing, Copyright and Creativity, Jeffries, J, and Kember, S. (eds.) Open Book Publishers. DOI: 10.11647/OBP.0159.01

“Protecting Sensitive Communication with Defensive Technology.” Howe, Daniel C. Chapter 25, in Boycott Classes, Continue Learning - A Review of the Theories and Thoughts Prior to the Umbrella Movement. Hong Kong: Step Forward Press, p239-251.

“TrackMeNot: Resisting Surveillance in Web Search.” Howe, Daniel C. and Nissenbaum, H. Chapter 23, in Lessons from the Identity Trail: Anonymity, Privacy and Identity in a Networked Society. Ian Kerr, Carole Lucock and Valerie Steeves (eds.) Oxford: Oxford University Press, p417–436.

“Values in Design: Theory and Practice.” Flanagan, M., Howe, D., & Nissenbaum, H. Embodying Values in Technology: Theory and Practice. “Informed Consent in the Mozilla Browser:  Implementing Value–Sensitive Design.” Friedman, B., Howe, D. C. and Felten, E. W. Chapter 9, in <em>Internet Security: Hacking, CounterHacking, and Society, K. E. Himma (editor).  Mass: Jones and Bartlett Publishers, p153–170.
